body:
The UK, and the Foreign and Commonwealth Office as a representative of the UK overseas, plays a critical role in demonstrating and promoting openness and transparency in government. 

The UK was a founding member in establishing of the open government partnership, an agenda now signed up to by 70 countries around the world. However there is still much to do to realise the vision set out by the pillars of the partnership.

This module explores the pillars of the OGP, the critical role of open data in each pillar and how the UK is pushing the 'open by default' agenda.

body:
The FCO is committed to open data. The department has published its list of commitments to publishing open data, and an open data strategy which outlines some of the high priority datasets including those related to aid, consular services and spending.

The FCO also makes use of a large amount of data and open data within internal activities, however challenges still exist in realising the benefits of a strong data strategy within the FCO.

This module looks at why data should be treated as a valuable raw resource and how a strong data strategy can help maximise benefits both internally and externally.

body: Transparency of information is a foundation of open government. But transparency alone is not enough to for the UK to maximise the wider economic, environment and social benefits.
title: 1. Transparency and open data

body: Open data sits at the heart of the open government movement. Open data presents significant economic, environment and social benefits, and is an integral part of delivering a first class foreign policy for the UK.
